Situation1: Their family members have recently emphasized the importance of maintaining long-held customs.
Expectation2: Follow laws and respect others’ rights and public property
Situation2: A weekend stroll through the park passes posted no-littering signs and a nearby trash bin.
Story: As I walked through the park with my stepfamily, the air was thick with the scent of spring and the weight of their words from breakfast still lingered. “We always leave a mark, a sign we were here,” my stepfather had said, reminding us of the family tradition to leave a small token—usually a ribbon or a note—wherever we went. Today, my stepsister handed me a bright red ribbon, her eyes expectant. “It’s your turn,” she whispered, nodding toward a low-hanging branch near the path. But right beside it, a city sign glared: “No Littering. Keep Our Parks Clean.” The trash bin was only a few steps away, a silent invitation to do what I knew was right as a citizen. My heart pounded as my family watched, waiting for me to honor our tradition, while the rules of the city pressed on my conscience. I could feel both sets of expectations tightening around me, each demanding loyalty, each impossible to ignore.
